data.text: @qh_murphy 100%. The Attack of Opportunity (and ESPECIALLY the Full Attack) led to just standing still in melee and wailing on each other.
@qh_murphy Amen, "theatre of the mind" and all that just does not work as well for me as a good square grid

@qh_murphy This was another thing that DND4 did really well, with the control based classes getting really great tools around AoOs and the mobility classes got really great tools around avoiding them.
@loganbonner @rdonoghue @qh_murphy Because it didn't matter how bad you were, it was a *free* bonus, and giving that up defintily required a very good reason to do so.

@loganbonner @rdonoghue @qh_murphy We used to have a running joke in one of my gaming groups, which was "$social_interaction? Don't forget to pull a knife!" because no matter what your role in the combat team was, you should pull a knife for the flanking bonus and the free AoO you got.

@SkiingMouse @qh_murphy @slavetothehat Non flip answer: Because without it, strength is even further reprioritized and Dexterity becomes even more uber because the optimal path for everyone becomes all bows, all the time. 

There's more to it, of course, but there's a value to keeping melee "sticky"
@rdonoghue @qh_murphy @slavetothehat Coming straight from DnD 1e I struggle to see what problem AoO solves. Seems to primarily make things much more complex...!

@qh_murphy No, that wasn't it. It was good idea and made combat more tactically challenging.

The real problem in limiting movement isn't the AoO or ways to reduce them. The real problem in 3.x/PF1 was the full attack action.
